title: 110_s137
content: The "Preserving Medicare for All Act of 2007" includes provisions for negotiating prices for Medicare prescription drugs, guaranteeing prescription drug benefits, providing full reimbursement for qualified retiree prescription drug plans, repealing certain cost adjustment programs, and removing exclusions for benzodiazepines from Medicare coverage. The Social Security Act is amended to allow the Secretary to negotiate prices with manufacturers of covered part D drugs to ensure beneficiaries pay the lowest price. There will be no national formulary or price structure to promote competition. The Secretary may not require a specific formulary or price structure for reimbursement of covered part D drugs to promote competition. SEC. 3. GUARANTEED PRESCRIPTION DRUG BENEFITS. Amends Section 1860D-3 of the Social Security Act to ensure access to a choice of qualified prescription drug coverage. Sec. 1860D-3 of the Social Security Act ensures each part D eligible individual has a choice of at least three plans, including a nationwide prescription drug plan and two qualifying plans in their area. The requirement is not met if only one entity offers all qualifying plans. For Sec. 1860D-3 of the Social Security Act, a qualifying plan is defined as a prescription drug plan, an MA-PD plan with basic or qualified prescription drug coverage, or a nationwide prescription drug plan offered by the Secretary. The Secretary, through the Administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, will qualify as a PDP sponsor to offer a nationwide prescription drug plan with basic coverage across the United States. The plan will have a $35 premium in 2008 and subsequent years. The Secretary, acting through the Administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, will offer a prescription drug plan with basic coverage nationwide. The plan will have a $35 premium in 2008 and subsequent years, with provisions for annual increases based on Medicare prescription drug cost growth. The plan must meet solvency and capital adequacy standards and utilize necessary authorities to ensure comparable offerings to private PDP sponsors. The Secretary may approve limited risk plans under section 1860D-11(f) to ensure access in certain areas. Section 1860D-11(g) is amended to state that a subsection will not apply after January 1, 2008. SEC. 4. FULL REIMBURSEMENT FOR QUALIFIED RETIREE PRESCRIPTION DRUG PLANS. Elimination of True Out-of-Pocket Limitation and Equalization of Subsidies under the Social Security Act for qualified retiree prescription drug plans. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will increase special subsidy payment amounts to match payments that would have been made if individuals were not under this Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will adjust subsidy payments for qualified retiree prescription drug plans to match payments that would have been made if individuals were not enrolled in such plans. This section and its amendments will be effective on January 1, 2008. The Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 are repealed, including the Comparative Cost Adjustment (CCA) Program, MA Regional Plan Stabilization Fund, and Cost Containment Provisions. SEC. 8. Removal of exclusion of benzodiazepines from required coverage under the Medicare Prescription Drug Program. The Medicare Prescription Drug Program will now cover benzodiazepines starting January 1, 2008. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will review policies to ensure appropriate use and prevent abuse. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will develop educational guidelines for physicians on prescribing benzodiazepines through Medicare Quality Improvement Organizations to ensure appropriate use and prevent abuse.
